msIdentifier.collection: Historical Society of Pennsylvania large graphics collection

history.acquisition: This collection includes engravings, lithographs, blueprints, architectural drawings, sketches, and watercolors. The images, which include posters, advertisements, landscapes, historical scenes, still-lifes, and portraits, had both decorative and commercial purposes. Among the artists represented are John Sartain, Henry Inman, Albert Newsam, Frank Taylor, Joseph Pennell, and Peter Rothermel. Architects include Frank Furness, William Strickland, and George B. Roberts.

projectDesc.p: The Historic Images, New Technologies (HINT) project aims to enhance description and discovery of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania's graphics materials and promote the linking and sharing of content among institutions and scholars. The project will result in an update to HSP's digital image viewer and an online digital history exhibit that will demonstrate the new viewer's capabilities and provide interpretive and contextual materials to encourage users to interact with historical images in new ways. This project was funded by a grant from the National Historical Publications and Records Commission's (NHPRC) Innovation in Archives and Documentary Editing program.

div.p: Cartoon depicts African American life both before and after the issuing of the Emancipation Proclamation. An idealized version of African American life is featured in the illustration along with renderings of the depravities of slave life. A large center circle shows an African American family (mother, father, children, grandparents) in a home going about daily life. Below this center circle is a oval portrait of Abraham Lincoln. Flanking the main circle and Lincoln portrait is complex imagery showing of hardships facing African Americans during slavery and the benefits of freedom following the Emancipation Proclamation.
This scene depicts fugitive slaves being chased through a swamp in the Confederate South prior to emancipation.

This scene depicts an African American slave being publicly auctioned as his wife, children, and other bystanders look on. The emphasis here is on the male slave's separation from his family against his will.

This third and final scene depicting the hardships of the life of slavees shows a man beting an African American woman with a whip as she is held down over a tree stump. Meanwhile, another slave is being painfully branded on his back. Two other enslaved people await their turn while a man wearing a tophat and smoking a pipe looks on.

Cerberus is a three-headed dog with a serpent's tail who, in Greek and Roman mythology, guards the entrance to the underworld. Here, one woman holds Cerberus's leash while another holds a flaming torch; all three flee from Freedom and Emancipation.
The word is depicted on a field of shining rays of light, as though from a sunrise.

Nast has included a rendering of the famous statue, "Freedom," that is mounted atop the dome of the Capitol building in Washington, D.C. This statue was cast by enslaved laborers, the most well-known of whom was Philip Reid. Reid was owned by the sculptor Clark Mills, who was commissioned to cast a version of Thomas Crawford's "Freedom" as the crowning detail of the Capitol dome.

In the central scene of this cartoon is three generations of an African American family enjoying life post-emancipation. A woman cooks on a stove labeled "Union" while a man bounces a baby on his knee. A male and female child look on. There is also an older woman reading and a couple having a conversation in the background. Presiding over the scene is a framed portrait of Abraham Lincoln hanging next to a banjo on the wall.

Abraham Lincoln, sixteenth President of the United States, issued the Emancipation Proclamation on January 1, 1863. The document declared "that all persons held as slaves" within the states in rebellion against the Union "henceforward shall be free." Though momentous, this document had many limitations and did not free any slaves in those slave-holding states which remained loyal to the Union during the Civil War.

A personified rendering of Justice, holding olive branch and scales, reaches up to the depictions of freedom and emancipation. Behind her, two men in what appear to be Union soldier uniforms enthusiastically plant a flag.

One of the advantages of African-American life after the Emancipation Proclamation that Nast imagines is homeownership, here depicted as a man playing a banjo for a woman as they sit on the shores of an idyllic lake against the background of a peaceful town.
Another benefit of life after emancipation is show in children gleefuly leaving their mother at home and entering a building labeled, Public School," over which the American flag flies.

A third benefit of a life free from slavery is earning a wage for work. This portion of the cartoon shows an African American man coming in from the cotton field and receiving his pay for a day's work at the cashier's window while others line up for their money behind him and a child looks on.
King & Baird, Printers, 607 Sansom Street, Philadelphia.
